hints.Patient Care: Providing compassionate, safe, and effective care for patients in various healthcare settings.
hints.Anatomy and Physiology: Understanding the structure and function of the human body to provide appropriate care.
hints.Medical Terminology: Learning the language used in healthcare to accurately describe medical conditions and treatments.
hints.Infection Control: Ensuring proper hygiene and infection prevention practices to protect patients and healthcare workers.
hints.Medication Administration: Safely administering medications and monitoring their effects on patients.
hints.First Aid and CPR: Providing emergency care to patients experiencing injuries or medical emergencies.
hints.Patient Assessment: Gathering information about a patient's health status through observation and questioning.
hints.Vital Signs: Measuring and monitoring indicators of a patient's health, such as heart rate, blood pressure, and temperature.
hints.Wound Care: Cleaning, dressing, and monitoring wounds to promote proper healing and prevent infection.
hints.Communication Skills: Effectively conveying information and collaborating with patients, families, and healthcare team members.
hints.Documentation: Accurately recording patient information and care provided in medical records.
hints.Cultural Competence: Respecting and understanding diverse cultural backgrounds to provide personalized care.
hints.Time Management: Prioritizing tasks and managing time effectively to provide efficient care.
hints.Ethics and Legal Issues: Adhering to ethical principles and legal regulations in nursing practice.
hints.Health Promotion and Disease Prevention: Educating patients and families about healthy lifestyle choices and ways to prevent illness.
